sa1.1-4:0.2: (1-4) Impermanent, Painful, Empty, and Not Self
sa1.1-4:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa1.1-4:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa1.1-4:2.2: “You must observe that form is [1] impermanent … [2] painful … [3] empty … [4] not self.
sa1.1-4:2.3: Such observation then is right view.
sa1.1-4:2.4: Correctly observing it, you’ll become disillusioned.
sa1.1-4:2.5: Being disillusioned, your delight and greed for it will end.
sa1.1-4:2.6: When your delight and greed for it have ended, that’s said to be the mind’s liberation.
sa1.1-4:3.4: consciousness is [1] impermanent … [2] painful … [3] empty … [4] not self.
sa1.1-4:3.5: Such observation then is right view.
sa1.1-4:3.6: Correctly observing it, you’ll become disillusioned.
sa1.1-4:3.7: Being disillusioned, your delight and greed for it will end.
sa1.1-4:3.8: When your delight and greed for it have ended, that’s said to be the mind’s liberation.
sa1.1-4:4.1: “Thus, monks, if your mind is liberated and you want to realize it yourself, then you will realize this:
sa1.1-4:4.2: ‘My births have been ended, the religious practice has been established, and the task has been accomplished.
sa1.1-4:4.3: I myself know that I won’t be subject to a later existence.’”
sa1.1-4:5.1: The monks who heard what the Buddha taught then rejoiced and approved.
